sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a circular loop
message_1: A circular loop of wire with a radius of 5 cm carries a current of 2 A. Calculate the magnetic field at the center of the loop.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field at the center of the loop, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a circular loop of wire:

B = (μ₀ * I * R²) / (2 * (R² + x²)^(3/2))

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current, R is the radius of the loop, and x is the distance from the center of the loop along its axis. In this case, we want to find the magnetic field at the center of the loop, so x = 0.

B = (μ₀ * I * R²) / (2 * (R²)^(3/2))

Plugging in the given values:

R = 5 cm = 0.05 m (converting to meters)
I = 2 A

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A * (0.05 m)²) / (2 * (0.05 m)²)^(3/2)

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A * 0.0025 m²) / (2 * 0.0025 m²)^(3/2)

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 0.0025 m²) / (0.0025 m²)^(3/2)

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 0.0025 m²) / (0.0025 m²)

B = 8π × 10^(-7) T

B ≈ 2.51 × 10^(-6) T

So, the magnetic field at the center of the loop is approximately 2.51 × 10^(-6) T.
